## Reason of admission
69 years old man admitted on the 2024-02-20 with abdominal pain and jaundice since a month back.

## Medical history
COPD. Anorexia nervosa. Gastrointestinal hemorrhage 2020 that were caused by esophageal varices. Smoker. Relapse of alcohol dependence in December. Sober since the middle of January.

## Treatment course
Patient had constant abdominal pain located around right arcus. Small amounts of stool that is loose and bright. Nausea but no vomiting. No fever. Jaundiced appearance of skin and sclerae. Inadequate compliance to medications. On examination spider naevi and suspected caput medusa on the abdomen and tender during palpation under the right arcus. CRP 51. Leukocytes 13,5. ASAT 4,52. ALAT 1,61. PK-INR 2,0. Bilirubin 680. Glasgow alcoholic hepatitis score 7 points. Cultures taken and patient receives piperacillin/tazobactam initially and Innohep for thrombus prophylaxis. Antibiotic treatment changed then to cefotaxim for spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Acute kidney injury stage 2. Creatinine 120. Decompensated with development of ascites. Patient receives Alburex. Gastroscopy 2024-02-22 shows esophageal varices with no indication for ligation. Patient developes severe itchiness and lots of pain in the abdomen. 
Receives Prednisolone for decompensated alcoholic hepatitis. Lab values normalizing after that and patient feels better and reached his daily caloric goal at least 2200 calories per day. Worsening after that with cascade vomiting with blood. Receives glypressin and Nexium. 1000 ml of RingerAcetate. Insertion of nasogastric tube and Erytromycin prior to the gastroscopy. Prednisolone paused. Second gastroscopy 2024-02-24 with ligationx4 of highly suspected bleeding from varices with red spots. Dose of Cefotaxime reduced to 1gx3. Nocturnal diarrhea  and potassium 3,0 as a result. Receives Kaleorid. 
Bilirubin 290, decreased from 680 previously. Alcoholic hepatitis is assessed to be self-terminating. No need for treatment with Prednisolone. Carvedilol started 2024-02-27 (ECG without signs of atrioventricular block)
Patient feels well with normalised bowel movements. No melena or hematochezia. Lactulose, 30 ml x 2 resumed. Potassium normalized. Kaleorid paused. Discharged from ward. 

## Medications
- Ciprofloxacin 500 Mg 1+0+1
- Beviplex 2+0+2
- Kaleorid	750	Mg	2+0+0
- Carvedilol 6.25 Mg 1+0+0
- Laktulos 670	Mg	20100+0+20100

## Plan after discharge
Patient referred to the gastroenterological office for a follow-up

## Procedures
- UJD02 Gastroscopy 2024-02-22
- UJD02 Gastroscopy 2024-02-24 

## Secondary diagnosis
- COPD 
- Anorexia nervosa
- Gastrointestinal hemorrhage

## Main diagnosis
K70.11 Alcoholic hepatitis with ascites

## Differential diagnosis
K70.4 Acute hepatic failure
